title: 104_hr4058
content: The "Mental Health Parity Act of 1996" is the short title of this Act. It provides plan protections for individuals with a mental illness. The "Mental Health Parity Act of 1996" ensures that group health plans with aggregate lifetime limits must include mental health services within those limits or establish a separate limit for such services. The Mental Health Parity Act of 1996 requires group health plans to have equal or higher limits for mental health services compared to lifetime limits for medical or surgical services. Plans without aggregate lifetime limits for medical or surgical services cannot impose such limits on mental health services. Annual limits may apply to group health plans offered by health insurance issuers. The Mental Health Parity Act of 1996 mandates that group health plans must have equal or higher annual limits for mental health services compared to medical or surgical services. Plans without lifetime limits for medical or surgical services cannot impose such limits on mental health services. The Mental Health Parity Act of 1996 requires group health plans to have equal or higher annual limits for mental health services compared to medical or surgical services. Plans without annual limits for medical or surgical services cannot impose limits on mental health services. The act allows for cost containment measures and distinctions between acute and chronic care. The Mental Health Parity Act of 1996 requires equal or higher annual limits for mental health services compared to medical or surgical services. The act does not apply to substance abuse benefits, health plans under title XVIII or XIX of the Social Security Act, or plans maintained by employers with less than 26 employees. State laws providing greater parity with mental health benefits are not preempted. Employers treated as a single entity under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are considered as one employer. For new employers, the determination of small employer status is based on the expected average number of employees in the current year. Any mention of an employer includes its predecessors. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "group health plan" under this Act refers to an employee welfare benefit plan that provides medical care to employees or their dependents through various means. "Medical care" includes amounts paid for diagnosis, treatment, prevention of disease, or affecting any structure. The term "health insurance coverage" includes benefits for medical care under policies offered by health insurance issuers, including items and services paid for as medical care. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a health insurance issuer, which includes insurance companies, organizations, and health maintenance organizations licensed to provide insurance in a state. It also mentions that a health insurance issuer is subject to state insurance regulations and includes plan sponsors for group health plans. The curr_chunk defines a health maintenance organization as a federally qualified organization, recognized under State law, or regulated for solvency. The term "State" includes several states and territories. The curr_chunk states that Section 2 will end on September 30, 2001, while sections 2 and 3 will start on October 1, 1997 for the Federal Employee Health Benefit Program. It also mentions an exemption if the Act results in a 1 percent or greater increase in premiums.
